experience_description: The racial makeup of my school is majority South Asian. The instances of Anti-Black racism often take place in the form of exclusionary acts and demeaning language. The more jarring behaviour such as usage of the n-slur and outdated racist rhetoric is reserved for hushed conversation, and is not at all easy to catch unless you are conscious of it and have figuratively dialled your ears in to the correct frequency. I do not report to admin when I am on the receiving end of anti-Black racism, but I refuse to sit idly as other Black students experience the same. I am in an executive position equivalent to President/Vice President/Founder at my school’s BIPOC Liberation Collective, and I owe it to the community and my people to be a voice or an amplifier of voices, rather, for students who experience anti-Black racism.

barriers_to_reporting: There are zero black administrators or counsellors to speak to, and the non-black ones have, notably, been unreliable when seeking support.
suggested_improvements: For one, the number of black teachers and staff could be increased. Instances of anti-black racism could be better penalized, and most importantly more effective anti-racism curriculum.
final_comments: A lot of the work I do in and out of the school environment centers around advocating for and disseminating anti-racist ideology in the school environment particularly. It is where I feel the safest. I am able to utilize the extensive reading I do on decolonization, education, and liberation, and pair it with my lived experiences as a Black girl in Canada.  It is liberating and impactful work, and in that way I can and do enact change.
